content: REVOLVING FUND. The United States Institute for Environmental Conflict Resolution Revolving Fund is established in the Treasury, administered by the Foundation. The Fund consists of appropriated amounts and payments. The Foundation will use the Fund for necessary expenses to operate the Institute, including salaries, administration, mediation services, and other reasonable expenses as determined by the Board. The Foundation will use the Revolving Fund for necessary expenses to establish and operate the Institute, including salaries, administration, mediation services, and other reasonable expenses as determined by the Board. The Revolving Fund will be maintained separately from the Trust Fund and will not be subject to certain program priorities. The Secretary of the Treasury will oversee the investment of amounts in the Fund. The Revolving Fund, distinct from the Trust Fund, will not be subject to certain program priorities. The Secretary of the Treasury will invest excess amounts in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. The Secretary of the Treasury will invest excess amounts from the Revolving Fund in interest-bearing obligations of the United States, either through original issue or purchase of outstanding obligations at market price. The Secretary of the Treasury can invest excess funds from the Revolving Fund in US obligations through original issue or purchase at market price. Obligations acquired can be sold at market price, with interest and proceeds credited back to the Revolving Fund. The Morris K. Udall Scholarship and Excellence in National Environmental and Native American Public Policy Act of 1992 is amended to allow the use of the Institute by a federal agency. The Morris K. Udall Scholarship and Excellence in National Environmental and Native American Public Policy Act of 1992 is amended to authorize federal agencies to utilize the Foundation and Institute for assessment, mediation, or related services in environmental, public lands, or natural resources disputes. Federal agencies can contract and pay for Institute services, with payments going into a Revolving Fund. Notification and concurrence procedures are also outlined. Federal agencies can contract and pay for Institute services, with payments going into a Revolving Fund. Agencies must notify the chairperson of the President's Council on Environmental Quality before using the Foundation or Institute for services. Before using the Foundation or Institute for services, federal agencies must notify the chairperson of the President's Council on Environmental Quality. The notification should include details about the issues, parties involved, prior efforts to address the issues, and other relevant information. In a case involving a dispute between federal agencies, the agency must obtain the concurrence of the chairperson of the President's Council on Environmental Quality. The written description should include details about the issues, parties involved, prior efforts to address the issues, and other relevant information. In cases of disagreement between federal agencies, the agency must seek approval from the chairperson of the President's Council on Environmental Quality before using the Foundation or Institute for services. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations for the Trust Fund and Revolving Fund, with specific amounts allocated for fiscal years 1998 through 2002. SEC. 9. Conforming amendments. SEC. 9. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amendments are made to the Morris K. Udall Scholarship and Excellence in National Environmental and Native American Public Policy Act of 1992, changing references from "Fund" to "Trust Fund" in various sections.
